description.summary: Divine serpent beings in Hindu and Buddhist mythology. Semi-divine race with cobra-like serpent form that can assume human or part-human form, dwelling in underground kingdoms and serving as guardians of treasures and water sources.
description.full: Nagas are a semi-divine race of serpent beings central to Hindu and Buddhist mythology. Depicted with multiple cobra heads (often 5, 7, or more), they possess the ability to shape-shift between serpent and human forms. Nagas dwell in Patala, the underground realm, where they guard vast treasures and water sources. They are immortal beings with control over weather, water, and magic. Famous nagas include Vasuki (used in the churning of the ocean), Shesha/Ananta (the cosmic serpent upon which Vishnu reclines), and Mucalinda (who protected the Buddha during meditation). Nagas can be benevolent protectors or malevolent destroyers depending on how they are treated. Their imagery is prominent in temple architecture throughout India and Southeast Asia, particularly at Angkor Wat and Thai temples.

forms.description: Full cobra form with multiple heads (typically 5, 7, or 9), cobra hood, jeweled crown
Human upper body with serpent lower body, or human with cobra hood

features.description: Often depicted with 5, 7, or more cobra heads
Precious gems and crowns adorning heads
Serpentine scales, often depicted as luminous or golden

physical.morphology: Semi-divine serpent beings capable of assuming multiple forms. Primary form is cobra-like with multiple heads. Can transform into human or part-human appearance at will.

abilities.description: Can transform between serpent, human, and hybrid forms
Command over rain, storms, and water
Dominion over rivers, lakes, and water sources
Various magical powers and supernatural abilities

patterns: Benevolent when respected, destructive when offended

range.description: Originating in Hindu mythology of India, naga beliefs spread throughout Southeast Asia with Buddhism and Hinduism

cultural_significance.significance: Divine beings, associates of major deities, cosmic serpents
Protectors of Buddha and dharma, particularly Mucalinda
Ancestral beings, prominent in Angkor Wat architecture
Water spirits, temple guardians, national symbol

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Hindu mythology, Vedic texts, pre-Hindu serpent worship traditions
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to worldwide serpent deity traditions, dragon mythology

timeline.significance: Earliest textual references to nagas in Vedic literature
Major naga stories including Vasuki and the churning of the ocean
Mucalinda protects Buddha during meditation, nagas incorporated into Buddhist cosmology
Naga beliefs spread to Cambodia, Thailand, Laos with Hindu-Buddhist influence
Massive naga sculptures and iconography in Khmer temple architecture

history.modern_era: Nagas remain central to living Hindu and Buddhist religious traditions. Featured prominently in temple architecture, festivals, and popular culture across South and Southeast Asia. National symbol of Thailand, Indonesia. Subject of continued religious veneration.

famous_nagas.name: Vasuki
famous_nagas.role: King of nagas, used as rope in churning of ocean (Samudra Manthan)
famous_nagas.significance: Central to creation myth of obtaining amrita (nectar of immortality)

famous_nagas.name: Shesha/Ananta
famous_nagas.significance: Supports the universe, symbol of infinity and eternity

famous_nagas.name: Mucalinda
famous_nagas.significance: Seven-headed naga king who shielded Buddha from storm

famous_nagas.name: Manasa
famous_nagas.significance: Daughter of Shiva, protector from snake bites

symbolism.spiritual_significance: In Hinduism and Buddhism, nagas represent the kundalini energy coiled at the base of the spine. They symbolize the potential for spiritual awakening and transformation. Their connection to water represents life-giving forces and fertility.

folklore.beliefs: Nagas control rainfall and water sources, must be propitiated for good harvests. Can bring prosperity or disaster. Marriage between humans and nagas in some regional myths.

examples: Indian temples - naga sculptures and iconography
architecture.description: Naga imagery is ubiquitous in Hindu and Buddhist temple architecture, particularly in Southeast Asia. Multi-headed nagas flank temple staircases, bridge railings, and roof decorations.

other: National emblem of Indonesia (Garuda fighting naga)

cultural_sensitivity.note: Nagas are part of living Hindu and Buddhist religious traditions. They are objects of active worship and veneration, not merely mythological creatures. Approach with respect for religious significance.
guidelines: Recognize nagas as sacred religious beings, not fictional monsters
Respect temple spaces where naga imagery appears
Understand cultural context when discussing or depicting nagas
Consult with Hindu and Buddhist scholars for religious interpretation
